(ref: q.php?date=201811291109)11.29.1811:09 am  If you think it would be fun, would you care to explain long long long journey?

came up with the chorus first. then i had to find verses. actually found the verse melody before any lyrics. knowing the chorus but not knowing the verse that starts the song is a very strange mystery to solve sometimes. writing forwards you can just ask what comes next. but figuring out what came before (writing backwards) is really strange. but after finding the verse melody, i started searching for lyrics, and 'remember' seemed to work best. 'i wonder if you remember' ... 'i remember the morning ...' 'do you remember the morning you said that it's over' ... i'm just reading what i wrote down in that writing session. these were all brainstormed lines for the first verse before i found the real thing. 'i wonder if you remember the place that we came from' . none of these are good enough .... ' i remember the first time i said something intelligent' ... 'i remember the moment i left where i came from ' ... 'i remember the first thing i said when i got here' ... There are some slightly more interesting ones but i can't tell you them. 'i'm slipping under the blanket where nobody sees me' i don't know if that was supposed to be for the first line or for another line but it fits the same melody. i can see the post card lyric floating around here. actually took quite a bit of brainstorming before the actual first line came to me (moment that my dreams were broken) and i very distinctively knew that had to be it. and then from there it's just coming up with lines are good enough. keep coming up with lines until one of them seems good enough. then keep going. etc. that's about all there is to it. and if you don't have a deadline you will never think anything is good enough, and if you have a deadline you still won't think it's good enough but that will force you to come up with something that is almost good enough maybe

Hey Bill, recently I've been thinking a lot about how augmented chords and how sad it is that they're almost never used. Do you know why that is?

i think it's an illusion, based on the fact that it has been taught to you in the same context as major and minor chords. but it's really not that. it's actually 1 of many variety of whole tone based chordal situations. which are not happy nor sad but kind of tense feeling. and they are best used as transitions, usually, .... and the one particular arrangement that may have been taught to you as an 'augmented' chord (the augmented triad) is just 1 of many ways to use that stuff
What are some cool ways that an aug chord could be used, perhaps an example from some music you like or have written?

if you get in a time machine and go to the late 70s and check out some minor key r&b songs, i think you may find that the 5 chord will be something like this: say it's the key of C minor, you're gonna see something called Gaug7 which has G in the bass and then it has F, B, and Eb in the chord. but this is not quite the thing you are talking about, although it is more common than the thing you are talking about. and it is still used today not just in the 70s

if it's so important for you to have the exact date your content was created/finished on your website, rather than the date it was published, why do your song dates still show the same day as the videos? Do you take a particular stance in the 440Hz vs 432Hz debate,
or is there somewhere else you go? Or do you simply not care?

we are living in a time where there is more agreement about tuning than ever before. because everything's digital, and programs default to 440. most people are pitch correcting their vocals, and it would be 440. even just 30 years ago, things were all over the place because things were on tape, and the speed could get changed either deliberately or not. my decision to stay in tune with the rest of the world is actually mostly out of convenience for other musicians. it happens to be very convenient that almost everything is 440, because if you have an instrument in your hand you can play along with anything. and when that old tape tune comes on that's out of key, you basically can't play to it unless you feel like re-tuning. it may sound fresh to avoid 440, but it doesn't ultimately make a difference, and it is very convenient for all the players out there if i stay in 440

Bill, I wanted to talk to you about something. I think that throughout my career as a musician I have contracted a virus that I can only identify as "bridge section fanatic syndrome" or something. It happens even with the classics, to me. Name an artist, I will likely be a fan of their bridges or "c sections" alone, even with their most classic songs. It happens with music from all eras (although lately I'm finding a lack in true bridge sections as an entity, if you will, specially in hip hop and trap, even though I enjoy a lot of the music). hi bill, i play the keys, and i'll eventually play with a band or other people, but i'm not sure how this accompaniment thing works. what i do right now is listen my favorite records and accompany them while listening. i play chord after chord after chord and that doesn't work for every song, sure it's fine for some but it doesn't sound good for some. you know a lot about music and i guess you've gone through this sometime. how do i make my accompaniments more exciting, like get some interesting melodic or rythmic stuff going instead of playing chords on the right and octave root notes at the left.

it's tricky because when you're playing along to a record, there is already accompaniment there. so actually there's probably already too much if you are playing too. also if there is already a bass player, you need to not play root notes in the bass, unless you are entirely sure that you and the bass player will play exactly the same thing at exactly the same time. it will be helpful if you can get some kind of play-along recording which has your instrument muted
